metadata.title: Effortless Hyperparameters Tuning with Spark | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Effortless Hyperparameters Tuning with Apache Spark
metadata.description: Parallel Hyperparameters tuning on Spark without writing Spark code.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Tantalus, unable to get a juicy fruit that is hanging just in front of me!
there’s this nice deck from Nan Zhu that explains how to do that

all_paragraphs: I still can’t decide if Hyperparameter Tuning is one of my favorite or least favorite steps when dealing with Machine Learning pipelines; on one side, it’s something that usually happens towards the end of projects: those meetings to define the problem, all the hours spent digging around for the data, weeks of developments of ETL scripts… distant memories, it’s time to see if things tie together! On the other hand, sometimes I feel like Tantalus, unable to get a juicy fruit that is hanging just in front of me!
If you ever had that feeling, this article could be a good starting point to speed up the process and simplify your life, especially with an Apache Spark infrastructure on tap!

I would define a hyperparameter of a learning algorithm as a piece of information that is embedded in the model before the training process, and that is not derived during the fitting. If the model is a Random Forest, examples of hyperparameters are: the maximum depth of the trees or how many features to consider when building each element of the forest.

If you ever have evaluated the quality of a ML model, you know that there is no one-size-fits-all configuration, as the same model can show dramatically different performance when we apply it to two distinct datasets; Hyperparameters Tuning is simply the process that aims to optimize that configuration to have the best performance possible out of the model we choose for our problem.

At a very high level, what we want to achieve using a Machine Learning algorithm, is minimizing a cost function (or maximize a quality metric) f(y_hat(x),y), where y_hat is the value predicted by the model (given a set of known features x) and y is the expected outcome.

Consider a ML algorithm with a single hyperparameter. If we fit the algorithm on a dataset and evaluate performance, we obtain a particular value of our cost function f. If we draw how the cost varies according to distinct hyperparameter choices, we end up having something like the following:

In the image above, one param selection gave us better results than the others in terms of cost function: we should probably select that one to build the final model. Above is the case in which we have a single hyperparameter and, by consequence, our search space is simply a curve. If our algorithm supports 2 hyperparameters, the search space turns to be a surface:
Again, we will select the pair of hyperparameters (hp_1,hp_2) that gives us the best cost function.
When we have k hyperparameters, the search must happen on a hypersurface of k dimensions; the more the params the harder the exploration.
What we need at this point is a strategy to navigate the hyperparameters space. There are two very simple methods that we can use:

As I wrote earlier, Hyperparams Optimization is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to ML processes. For this demo, we’d actually need to define the problem and gather the data. Luckily for us, some lovely people already did that. We are going to use the Kaggle Mercedes-Benz Greener Manufacturing Competition, which took place in 2017. In Mercedes-Benz own words: In this competition, Daimler is challenging Kagglers to tackle the curse of dimensionality and reduce the time that cars spend on the test bench. Competitors will work with a dataset representing different permutations of Mercedes-Benz car features to predict the time it takes to pass testing. Winning algorithms will contribute to speedier testing, resulting in lower carbon dioxide emissions without reducing Daimler’s standards.
The reasons why I choose this dataset/problem are:
Enough for the introduction, let’s jump to the fun stuff.

The dataset consists of a few categorical variables, a fairly large number of binary variables and the dependant is continuous. Mercedes-Benz obfuscated the table, so the features are only known as X_i. If you want an extensive data analysis, I’d suggest you go on the competition page and check out the notebooks made by the community! The metric proposed for the evaluation is the coefficient of determination, R², we‘ll stick to that to compare the models. We will use XGBoost to do the predictions, an optimized distributed gradient boosting library that implements machine learning algorithms under the Gradient Boosting framework [1]
What we are trying to achieve is running a parallel Grid/Random search using a Spark infrastructure. Apache Spark comes bundled with some Machine Learning tools (MLLib). Let’s forget about that!

I can hear your objection: yes, XGBoost Grid Search could be achieved using MLLib pipelines (there’s this nice deck from Nan Zhu that explains how to do that), but I believe that MLLib doesn’t give enough flexibility for params tuning: at the end of the day, you might want to use a more intelligent algorithm, and pure Python will make the implementation easier; with the idea below, you should be able to run many types of search (Bayesian, Genetic) without the hustle of dealing with the Spark APIs: everything will mostly be written in plain Python!
Let’s do another step and define what’s the high-level methodology. For the scope of this article, we need to do a minimal preprocessing: the only purpose is to make the dataset readable by XGBoost.
What we will do is as simple as:
As I specified above, the competition was based on the R², so we’ll keep using this metric to probe the models’ performance; more precisely, the evaluation algorithm will be the following:
Awesome! Now we are finally ready to implement the algorithm!

The first step when running either Grid or Random search is to define the search space. XGBoost has many, many parameters that can be set before the fitting. For our problem, we are going to use the tree booster (the library offers other options too), and we’ll focus only on the following params:

learning_rate: Step size shrinkage used in the update to prevent overfitting. After each boosting step, we can directly get the weights of new features and eta shrinks the feature weights to make the boosting process more conservative. [xgboost parameters]
colsample_bytree: is the subsample ratio of columns when constructing each tree. Subsampling occurs once for every tree constructed. [xgboost parameters]

subsample: Subsample ratio of the training instances. Setting it to 0.5 means that XGBoost would randomly sample half of the training data prior to growing trees. and this will prevent overfitting. Subsampling will occur once in every boosting iteration. [xgboost parameters]
n_estimators: The numbers of trees used by the algorithm.
reg_alpha: L1 regularization term on weights. Increasing this value will make the model more conservative. [xgboost parameters]
max_depth: Maximum depth of a tree. Increasing this value will make the model more complex and more likely to overfit. [xgboost parameters]
gamma: Minimum loss reduction required to make a further partition on a leaf node of the tree. The larger gamma is, the more conservative the algorithm will be. [xgboost parameters]

As you can imagine, the above is a pretty big search space! When we do hyperparameters tuning, though, we are not completely groping in the dark. Many ML methods (and XGBoost as well) have guidelines that can help to define meaningful ranges for all the params of the grid. For example, even if know that the learning_rate can be in [0,1], it’s unlikely that values close to 1 will lead to good results. The following Python dictionary represents the search space that I have selected for the Mercedes-Benz problem:

The dictionary above would lead to 6,890,400 points to probe. Note that, even if every test needs 1 second to complete, we would need approximately 79 days and 18 hours of continuous computation time to explore the whole grid! Grid Search will never try all those combinations.
The following function returns the grid as a Python generator (to avoid having a big data structure in memory):
Now that we have the search space, let’s try to implement Grid search locally.
First of all, we need a method to evaluate the R²:
Then we define a function grid_search with the following signature:
The search algorithm will be terminated after timeout_seconds. The Cross-Validation will use cv_splits number of splits and XGBoost will use boosting_rounds iterations:
Moreover, we will collect the results in a Pandas dataframe for analysis:
Awesome. Let’s run the code above for one hour, grab a coffee and save the results for later.

We can recycle most of the code above to implement the Random Search, the only difference is that we do not need to pre-define the grid: we can just declare a function that returns a random point of the exploration surface:
Then we can slightly modify the Grid Search loop:
Again: run, coffee, wait for the results.
The whole point of this article is to explain how to parallelize the algorithms above using a Spark infrastructure. We will focus only on Random Search.
We can approach the problem using various strategies:

Before looking at the implementation, we need to specify the architecture that we will be using. In particular, once the algorithm will have the results of the Cross-Validations, it will need to spit them out “somewhere” (for us to collect and analyze). We’ll use a MongoDB instance:

The diagram above shows that we will have the entry point in a Jupyter notebook. Through one of the cells we will use Joblib-Spark to send the executions to the different nodes; in addition, on each node we will use plain Joblib to enable multithreading. Finally, each executor will write the results in a MongoDB instance sitting on another server.
The preprocessing code will remain the same and we can re-use the function for generating random combinations, so let’s write the loop that will do the magic:
The Joblib magic happens at the following line:

What’s happening under the hood? Joblib-Spark will send the function over the wire (using cloud-pickle for the serialization). Then through the parallelize Spark method, each execution will be sent to a single node.
We need to build the evaluate function that will be executed on each Spark machine:

As you can see we are defining an inner function within the evaluate. This is needed because, besides parallelizing the grid search over Spark, we also want to use multithreading on the single executor. The following line shows the usage of (plain) Joblib with the default backend:
Let’s run the random_search_spark function above for one hour and save the results in our MongoDB instance. What we expect to see on the Spark UI, are three stages that will run for one hour each:
The journey is coming to an end. We have collected all the results and we only need to analyze them!

Spark tests have been running on a Cluster composed by 3 Machines (1 Driver + 2 Executors) with 4 Cores each, while the “local” search algorithms have been executed on a single machine. We used the following constants for all the methods.
The first interesting insight is simply the comparison of how many tests have been executed by each method:
In this case, we had a boost of 3x, which is a linear growth given the numbers of nodes (note: the “local” versions still had 4 cores available).
To have a sense of “how” methods explored the hypersurface, let’s plot the R² obtained by the algorithms:
From the charts above there are at least two takeaways:
The best parameters found by the methods:

Note that Grid Search won, even if it was able to do only 32 attempts! The outcome from the results above is that we should probably rethink which hyperparameters to tune and how to define the grid/ranges. We can see, for example, that all the methods agree on the fact that the learning_rate should be in [0.01,0.05], while in our grid we set the maximum value to be 0.25: we probably wasted a lot of computation time looking in the wrong zones of the hypersurface! (A side note: max_depth=3 makes me think that, maybe, many variables could be removed from the dataset, but that’s another story).

I think that the results above can lead to the following question: Can we put some intelligence into the exploration algorithm and do something smarter than this? The answer is “yes, we can”, but that’s the topic for another post! Before leaving, if you read until here, you deserve the link to the final notebook!
I hope you enjoyed! Let me know what you think and, if you want, check out these other articles!
I’m a Data Scientist, I usually ride a giant unicorn with a rainbow mane. I love learning by explaining. “Like a bicycle I need to move to keep my balance”.

a set of tools to provide lightweight pipelining in Python (transparent disk-caching of functions and lazy re-evaluation (memoize pattern), easy simple parallel computing). Joblib is optimized to be fast and robust on large data in particular and has specific optimizations for numpy arrays
